25#ifdef V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
26
27// Best-effort function to determine the approximate size of the virtual
28// address space that can be addressed by this process. Used to determine
29// appropriate sandbox size and placement.
30// The value returned by this function will always be a power of two.
31static Address DetermineAddressSpaceLimit() {
32#ifndef V8_TARGET_ARCH_64_BIT
33#error Unsupported target architecture.
34#endif
35
36 // Assume 48 bits by default, which seems to be the most common configuration.
37 constexpr unsigned kDefaultVirtualAddressBits = 48;
38 // 36 bits should realistically be the lowest value we could ever see.
39 constexpr unsigned kMinVirtualAddressBits = 36;
40 constexpr unsigned kMaxVirtualAddressBits = 64;
41
42 unsigned hardware_virtual_address_bits = kDefaultVirtualAddressBits;
43#if defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_X64)
44 base::CPU cpu;
45 if (cpu.exposes_num_virtual_address_bits()) {
46 hardware_virtual_address_bits = cpu.num_virtual_address_bits();
47 }
48#endif // V8_TARGET_ARCH_X64
49
50#if defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64) && defined(V8_TARGET_OS_ANDROID)
51 // On Arm64 Android assume a 40-bit virtual address space (39 bits for
52 // userspace and kernel each) as that appears to be the most common
53 // configuration and there seems to be no easy way to retrieve the actual
54 // number of virtual address bits from the CPU in userspace.
55 hardware_virtual_address_bits = 40;
56#endif
57
58 // Assume virtual address space is split 50/50 between userspace and kernel.
59 hardware_virtual_address_bits -= 1;
60
61 // Check if there is a software-imposed limits on the size of the address
62 // space. For example, older Windows versions limit the address space to 8TB:
63 // https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/memory/memory-limits-for-windows-releases).
64 Address software_limit = base::SysInfo::AddressSpaceEnd();
65 // Compute the next power of two that is larger or equal to the limit.
66 unsigned software_virtual_address_bits =
67 64 - base::bits::CountLeadingZeros(software_limit - 1);
68
69 // The available address space is the smaller of the two limits.
70 unsigned virtual_address_bits =
71 std::min(hardware_virtual_address_bits, software_virtual_address_bits);
72
73 // Guard against nonsensical values.
74 if (virtual_address_bits < kMinVirtualAddressBits ||
75 virtual_address_bits > kMaxVirtualAddressBits) {
76 virtual_address_bits = kDefaultVirtualAddressBits;
77 }
78
79 return 1ULL << virtual_address_bits;
80}
81
82void Sandbox::Initialize(v8::VirtualAddressSpace* vas) {
83 // Take the size of the virtual address space into account when determining
84 // the size of the address space reservation backing the sandbox. For
85 // example, if we only have a 40-bit address space, split evenly between
86 // userspace and kernel, then userspace can only address 512GB and so we use
87 // a quarter of that, 128GB, as maximum reservation size.
88 Address address_space_limit = DetermineAddressSpaceLimit();
89 // Note: this is technically the maximum reservation size excluding the guard
90 // regions (which are not created for partially-reserved sandboxes).
91 size_t max_reservation_size = address_space_limit / 4;
92
93 // In any case, the sandbox should be smaller than our address space since we
94 // otherwise wouldn't always be able to allocate objects inside of it.
95 CHECK_LT(kSandboxSize, address_space_limit);
96
97 if (!vas->CanAllocateSubspaces()) {
98 // If we cannot create virtual memory subspaces, we fall back to creating a
99 // partially reserved sandbox. This will happen for example on older
100 // Windows versions (before Windows 10) where the necessary memory
101 // management APIs, in particular, VirtualAlloc2, are not available.
102 // Since reserving virtual memory is an expensive operation on Windows
103 // before version 8.1 (reserving 1TB of address space will increase private
104 // memory usage by around 2GB), we only reserve the minimal amount of
105 // address space here. This way, we don't incur the cost of reserving
106 // virtual memory, but also don't get the desired security properties as
107 // unrelated mappings may end up inside the sandbox.
108 max_reservation_size = kSandboxMinimumReservationSize;
109 }
110
111 // If the maximum reservation size is less than the size of the sandbox, we
112 // can only create a partially-reserved sandbox.
113 bool success;
114 size_t reservation_size = std::min(kSandboxSize, max_reservation_size);
115 DCHECK(base::bits::IsPowerOfTwo(reservation_size));
116 if (reservation_size < kSandboxSize) {
117 DCHECK_GE(max_reservation_size, kSandboxMinimumReservationSize);
118 success = InitializeAsPartiallyReservedSandbox(vas, kSandboxSize,
119 reservation_size);
120 } else {
121 DCHECK_EQ(kSandboxSize, reservation_size);
122 constexpr bool use_guard_regions = true;
123 success = Initialize(vas, kSandboxSize, use_guard_regions);
124 }
125
126 // Fall back to creating a (smaller) partially reserved sandbox.
127 while (!success && reservation_size > kSandboxMinimumReservationSize) {
128 reservation_size /= 2;
129 DCHECK_GE(reservation_size, kSandboxMinimumReservationSize);
130 success = InitializeAsPartiallyReservedSandbox(vas, kSandboxSize,
131 reservation_size);
132 }
133
134 if (!success) {
135 V8::FatalProcessOutOfMemory(
136 nullptr,
137 "Failed to reserve the virtual address space for the V8 sandbox");
138 }
139
140#if V8_ENABLE_WEBASSEMBLY && V8_TRAP_HANDLER_SUPPORTED
141 trap_handler::SetV8SandboxBaseAndSize(base(), size());
142#endif // V8_ENABLE_WEBASSEMBLY && V8_TRAP_HANDLER_SUPPORTED
143
144 DCHECK(initialized_);
145}
146
147bool Sandbox::Initialize(v8::VirtualAddressSpace* vas, size_t size,
148 bool use_guard_regions) {
149 CHECK(!initialized_);
150 CHECK(base::bits::IsPowerOfTwo(size));
151 CHECK(vas->CanAllocateSubspaces());
152
153 size_t reservation_size = size;
154 if (use_guard_regions) {
155 reservation_size += 2 * kSandboxGuardRegionSize;
156 }
157
158 Address hint = RoundDown(vas->RandomPageAddress(), kSandboxAlignment);
159
160 // There should be no executable pages mapped inside the sandbox since
161 // those could be corrupted by an attacker and therefore pose a security
162 // risk. Furthermore, allowing executable mappings in the sandbox requires
163 // MAP_JIT on macOS, which causes fork() to become excessively slow
164 // (multiple seconds or even minutes for a 1TB sandbox on macOS 12.X), in
165 // turn causing tests to time out. As such, the maximum page permission
166 // inside the sandbox should be read + write.
167 address_space_ = vas->AllocateSubspace(
168 hint, reservation_size, kSandboxAlignment, PagePermissions::kReadWrite);
169
170 if (!address_space_) return false;
171
172 reservation_base_ = address_space_->base();
173 base_ = reservation_base_ + (use_guard_regions ? kSandboxGuardRegionSize : 0);
174 size_ = size;
175 end_ = base_ + size_;
176 reservation_size_ = reservation_size;
177 sandbox_page_allocator_ =
178 std::make_unique<base::VirtualAddressSpacePageAllocator>(
179 address_space_.get());
180
181 if (use_guard_regions) {
182 Address front = reservation_base_;
183 Address back = end_;
184 // These must succeed since nothing was allocated in the subspace yet.
185 CHECK(address_space_->AllocateGuardRegion(front, kSandboxGuardRegionSize));
186 CHECK(address_space_->AllocateGuardRegion(back, kSandboxGuardRegionSize));
187 }
188
189 initialized_ = true;
190
191 FinishInitialization();
192
193 DCHECK(!is_partially_reserved());
194 return true;
195}
196
197bool Sandbox::InitializeAsPartiallyReservedSandbox(v8::VirtualAddressSpace* vas,
198 size_t size,
199 size_t size_to_reserve) {
200 CHECK(!initialized_);
201 CHECK(base::bits::IsPowerOfTwo(size));
202 CHECK(base::bits::IsPowerOfTwo(size_to_reserve));
203 CHECK_LT(size_to_reserve, size);
204
205 // Use a custom random number generator here to ensure that we get uniformly
206 // distributed random numbers. We figure out the available address space
207 // ourselves, and so are potentially better positioned to determine a good
208 // base address for the sandbox than the embedder.
209 base::RandomNumberGenerator rng;
210 if (v8_flags.random_seed != 0) {
211 rng.SetSeed(v8_flags.random_seed);
212 }
213
214 // We try to ensure that base + size is still (mostly) within the process'
215 // address space, even though we only reserve a fraction of the memory. For
216 // that, we attempt to map the sandbox into the first half of the usable
217 // address space. This keeps the implementation simple and should, In any
218 // realistic scenario, leave plenty of space after the actual reservation.
219 Address address_space_end = DetermineAddressSpaceLimit();
220 Address highest_allowed_address = address_space_end / 2;
221 DCHECK(base::bits::IsPowerOfTwo(highest_allowed_address));
222 constexpr int kMaxAttempts = 10;
223 for (int i = 1; i <= kMaxAttempts; i++) {
224 Address hint = rng.NextInt64() % highest_allowed_address;
225 hint = RoundDown(hint, kSandboxAlignment);
226
227 reservation_base_ = vas->AllocatePages(
228 hint, size_to_reserve, kSandboxAlignment, PagePermissions::kNoAccess);
229
230 if (!reservation_base_) return false;
231
232 // Take this base if it meets the requirements or if this is the last
233 // attempt.
234 if (reservation_base_ <= highest_allowed_address || i == kMaxAttempts)
235 break;
236
237 // Can't use this base, so free the reservation and try again
238 vas->FreePages(reservation_base_, size_to_reserve);
239 reservation_base_ = kNullAddress;
240 }
241 DCHECK(reservation_base_);
242
243 base_ = reservation_base_;
244 size_ = size;
245 end_ = base_ + size_;
246 reservation_size_ = size_to_reserve;
247 initialized_ = true;
248 address_space_ = std::make_unique<base::EmulatedVirtualAddressSubspace>(
249 vas, reservation_base_, reservation_size_, size_);
250 sandbox_page_allocator_ =
251 std::make_unique<base::VirtualAddressSpacePageAllocator>(
252 address_space_.get());
253
254 FinishInitialization();
255
256 DCHECK(is_partially_reserved());
257 return true;
258}
259
260void Sandbox::FinishInitialization() {
261 // Reserve the last page in the sandbox. This way, we can place inaccessible
262 // "objects" (e.g. the empty backing store buffer) there that are guaranteed
263 // to cause a fault on any accidental access.
264 // Further, this also prevents the accidental construction of invalid
265 // SandboxedPointers: if an ArrayBuffer is placed right at the end of the
266 // sandbox, a ArrayBufferView could be constructed with byteLength=0 and
267 // offset=buffer.byteLength, which would lead to a pointer that points just
268 // outside of the sandbox.
269 size_t allocation_granularity = address_space_->allocation_granularity();
270 bool success = address_space_->AllocateGuardRegion(
271 end_ - allocation_granularity, allocation_granularity);
272 // If the sandbox is partially-reserved, this operation may fail, for example
273 // if the last page is outside of the mappable address space of the process.
274 CHECK(success || is_partially_reserved());
275
276 InitializeConstants();
277}
278
279void Sandbox::InitializeConstants() {
280 // Place the empty backing store buffer at the end of the sandbox, so that any
281 // accidental access to it will most likely hit a guard page.
282 constants_.set_empty_backing_store_buffer(end_ - 1);
283}
284
285void Sandbox::TearDown() {
286 if (initialized_) {
287 // This destroys the sub space and frees the underlying reservation.
288 address_space_.reset();
289 sandbox_page_allocator_.reset();
290 base_ = kNullAddress;
291 end_ = kNullAddress;
292 size_ = 0;
293 reservation_base_ = kNullAddress;
294 reservation_size_ = 0;
295 initialized_ = false;
296 constants_.Reset();
297 }
298}
299
300DEFINE_LAZY_LEAKY_OBJECT_GETTER(Sandbox, GetProcessWideSandbox)

302#endif // V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
